They also state that Buell hung five citizens of Lincoln county in retaliation.
The enemy cannot move but in large forces.
The guerrillas are killing them daily.

div4.p: August 10th, 1862. at the residence of her husband, Mr. Thomas E. West, Union Hill, Mrs. Lucy A West, aged 23 years.

div4.head: Obituaries.
div4.p:
Lt. C. F. Lyon.--Among the many noble spirits who have fallen in the present struggle for Southern independence, stands the name of Lt. C. F. Lyon, Co. F, 1st N. C. Regiment.
Wounded in the desperate charge against the enemy's battery at Ellison's Mill, Thursday, June 26th, his company and friends were sanguine of his recovery, and the announcement of his death found them unprepared for such mournful intelligence.
When the "Old North State" marshalled her patriotic sons to repel the Yankee invader, Lt. Lyon was among the first to enlist.
Leaving a pleasant and desirable situation, he connected himself with and became a Lieutenant in the "Hertford Grays"--afterwards Co. F, in the regiment commanded by the lamented Col. Stokes.
Intelligent, kind-hearted, and enthusiastic in the cause, he soon became an ornament to the regiment and the pride of the company to which he belonged.
Had a soldier been wronged, he well know that the noble, kind hearted Lyon would see him righted and redress his grievances.
He went into the fight at Ellyson's mill calmly and bravely, determined to strike a blow for freedom and his native South.
In the charge, the recollection of which is painful to the 1st North Carolina regiment, on account of the loss of two brave field officers, and many other gallant men, he received the wound that caused his death.
Conveyed to Richmond and from that point to his uncle's at Petersburg, his company cherished the hope that kind attention and skillful medical treatment would soon restore him to them.
But he has fallen.
Nothing remains but for them to emulate his virtues, and a determination to wreak vengeance on the minions of Abe Lincoln.
As one of his company who knew him well and admired his many excellent qualities of head and heart, the writer of this imperfect sketch would beg leave to add a word of praise to the memory of the gallant soldier and gentleman, Lieut. C. F. Lyon. He sleeps well.
The warrior's task is complete, his sword has been laid aside; he answers not to the battle call now; his spirit has taken its flight, and we turn away to drop a tear to his memory. T. D. B.
Petersburg Express please copy.

Died, at the residence of her father, in Hanover county, of typhoid fever, on the 4th day of August, 1862, Miss Lavinia Butler, in the 26th year of her age, leaving a father, mother, and two sisters, to mourn their untimely and irreparable loss.

The unexpected and sudden demise of Miss Butler has created a vacancy not easily filled.
While yet a girl she embraced the Christian religion, and always walked worthy the vocation wherewith she was called — a bright example to all who knew her. Her many virtues will live in the remembrance of her friends.
Those who worship at Bethesda feel deeply their loss.

Died, at Ashland, Hanover co, Va. May 28th, after a short illness, Mr. Nicholas W. Clarke, of Maryland, a member of the Amelia Troop, 1st Regiment Virginia Cavalry.
Death under all circumstances is saddening, but was peculiarly so in the case of this brave young soldier, who had long ago said "farewell" to home and its loved and gallantly buckled on his armor to lend his feeble strength in driving back a hated and merciless foe. In his death his comrades have lost a warm and noble hearted friend, a companion whose example always led stern deeds of valor and daring, and his native State one of her brightest jewels.
Richmond papers please copy.

div3.head:
Adjutant-General's Office, Va.,
Wytheville, August 4, 1862.
div3.p: the force which has been placed in the field having proved inadequate to the defence of the State, many portions of which are invaded by marauding bands of the enemy, who insult, oppress, and rob our people; and the Northern Government, smarting under their recent defeats around Richmond and elsewhere, having called for an additional force of 300,000 men, with the purpose of continuing their aggressions upon Virginia and the other States of the Confederacy, the Governor feels it to be his solemn duty to call upon the militia not now in service to unite with him in a prompt and vigorous effort to repel the enemy, to rescue the soil of the State and our people from the pollution and tyranny of a detestable foe, now appeals to the men of the following named counties, from 35 to 45 years of age, to wit: The counties of Washington, Smyth, Grayson, Carroll, Floyd, Pulaski, Wythe, Montgomery, Roanoke, Botetourt, Craig, Allegheny, Greenbrier, Monroe, Giles, Mercer, Bland, Tazewell, McDowell, Wise, Buchanan, Lee, Scott, Russell, Raleigh, Wyoming, Logan, Boone, Wayne, Cabell, Putnam, Kanawha, Mason, Clay, Nicholas, Fayette, Braxton, Webster, Pocahontas, and Randolph.

And as the organization of the several regiments of militia has been deranged by the going into service of so many officers and men, that it cannot be known at headquarters who the commandants are, the presiding justice of each county is required to proceed immediately to call out and cause to be embodied the militia men of his county between 35 and 45 years of age, without regard to regimental bounds; and to that end he is authorized to call upon one or more justices and the Commissioner or Commissioners of the Revenue to aid him.

When the number of men for each county is made up, the presiding justice will place them under the command of some intelligent and reliable man as officer in charge, with instructions to march the detachment as speedily as possible to the Salt Works, in Smyth county, and report to Maj.Gen. John B. Floyd for service.
Where there is railroad transportation, he will give such officer a certificate to enable him to obtain transportation for himself and the detachment, on account of the State.
The men will be allowed commutation in money for subsistence from the day they march until their arrival at the rendezvous.
The Governor most earnestly exhorts all who are now called upon to be prompt and vigorous in action; the movement is of vital consequence to the State, and there is not a day to spare.
div3.closer: By command. Wm. H; Richardson, A. G. au 15--3t

div3.head: Attention, officers.
div3.p:
--A non-conscript who has been soldiering for ten years, and understands the official duty of the Quartermaster Commissary and Ordnance Departments; also, Division, Brigade, Regimental, Company, and all army papers, will accept a situation in either department.
Address me at this office, stating where an interview can be bad.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway on Saturday, August 9th, my boy Tom. He is about 18 years of age, bright mulatto, about 5 feet 6 inches high, has a small flesh mark on his neck — no other mark recollected.
He had on when he left a linen coat and pants and gray military cap. Supposed to have gone away with a company from Mobile, connected with General Longstreet's division, on their way to Gordonsville.
I will give a reward of $50, if taken in this city; $100, if taken outside of our pickets around the city.
When last seen he was lurking about the Bailey hospital, on Cary street. P. K. White,
au 15--7t* 73 Main street, Richmond.

div3.head: Five dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from subscriber, on the evening of the 13th instant, my mulatto boy, Andrew.
He is nearly six feet high; has bushy hair; speaks humbly, and in a gross tone; had on a brown pair of pants when he left, and an overshirt of nearly the same color, Perhaps he may now be in the guard house.
If so, the officer in charge of it will please see that he receives 39 lashes before he is released.
Swift Galloway,
Lieutenant 3d reg't North Carolina troops.
U. S. Hotel Hospital, Aug. 14, '62. au 15--2t*

div3.head: Ranaway.
div3.p:
--Boy Dan ranaway from my son, who is in the 15th Alabama regiment, after the battles at Richmond, as he was going up the Valley from there.
He is about 40 or 45 years old, about 5 feet 7 inches high, very dark, rather slender made, his hair tolerably far back on his forehead, very quick spoken.
He was seen in Richmond a few days ago. Any person taking him up and putting him in jail will confer a favor, and I will pay them for their trouble.
Henry Maybin,
au 15--3t* Henry county, Ala.

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the apprehension and delivery to us of a negro boy named George, belonging to Mr. C. M. Ragland, of Scottsville.
Is about 16 years old, black and very likely, about five feet high.
He has been living in this city until recently, and his mother is hired to Mr. D. Ratcliffe, on Broad street, opposite Monumental Church.
au 14--4t* Ragland & Brother.

div3.head: Thirty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--The above reward of $30 will be paid for the apprehension and delivery of my man Lyneas, who ranaway on the 1st of July last.
He is about 20 years old, and about 5 feet 9 or 10 inches high; a mulatto, with very black, straight hair; large, Hazel eyes; thick lips, and walks very straight.
I have recently heard that he was with one of the Georgia regiments, near Richmond, and may procure free papers.
B. B. Ayres, American Hotel.
au 15--12t* Richmond, Va.
